newsitem.title: BELGIUM: BELGIAN QUICK STORMS HIGHER, SOME ASK WHY.
newsitem.headline: BELGIAN QUICK STORMS HIGHER, SOME ASK WHY.

text.p: Shares in Belgian hamburger chain Quick led the Brussels bourse higher in early trade on Thursday.
By 0830 GMT, Quick was up 6.67 percent at 2,240 francs, taking its gain over the last two sessions to more than 10 percent.
Quick's move started Wednesday on news Antwerp brokerage Bank Delen rated the stock a buy. Analyst Gert De Mesure said he had a target price for the stock of 2,400 to 2,500 francs.
Traders and other analysts were sceptical. "Frankly, I remain very cautious," one trader at another brokerage said.

"I think the move is a bit exaggerated," analyst Sandra Vandersmissen at Generale Bank said. "If it goes up much more I would think about a sell opportunity. Sales may have been up 10 percent in the first half, but that says nothing about same store sales. We will only know those after first half results."
Kredietbank said in its August summary of share recommendations -- when Quick was at 2,030 francs -- it had a "neutral minus" stance on the company.
Current net earnings per share were likely to be 98 francs in 1997, up from 91 francs in 1996, it said.
Another trader said, however, that he was not surprised by the move, given widespread newspaper coverage on Thursday of Wednesday's move in an otherwise quiet period.
The 2,100 francs level was also important technically for the share, he said. Once that was broken -- as happened in early trade -- it was bound to go higher.
Quick's rise failed to give a lift to its main shareholder, retailer GIB, whose shares were down five francs at 1,850 francs, bucking the general market trend.
The Bel-20 index, of which GIB is a component, was up 0.60 percent at 2,481.05 points.
